dungeonette.domain

Class Room

  • java.lang.Object
    • dungeonette.domain.Room

  • public class Room
extends java.lang.Object
    Object class for the rooms placed into the dungeon. The class contains a lot of program logic and lacks proper setters and getters.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Room

        public Room(java.awt.Point location,
            java.awt.Dimension dimension,
            int newID,
            char from,
            java.util.Random randomi)
        Constructor for a room in a dungeon floor.
        Parameters:
        location - Coarse 10x10 location of the room
        dimension - Fine 1x1 dimensions of the room (legal dimensions: 10x10,10x20,20x10,20x20 and 30x30). Each unit represents one tile (map coordinate)
        newID - Serial number of the room (unclear wether serial numbers should be reset for each floor or keep persistently incrementing throughout the entire multi-floor dungeon)
        from - Direction (n-s-w-e) of the rooms previous connecting room ("parent room")
        randomi - Random object received from Specification object

    • Method Detail

      • getTile

        public char getTile(int x,
                    int y,
                    boolean trueForTileFalseForItem)
        Fetches a tile represented as a char from as specific coordinate of the room. This coordinate matches the exact coordinates of a dungeon floor. While the room is situated on a coarse 10x10 grid (or multiple grids), the actual room tiles have fine 1x1 coordinates.
        Parameters:
        x - Fine x coordinate on the dungeon floor.
        y - Fine y coordinate on the dungeon floor.
        trueForTileFalseForItem - set true if you want to fetch the actual TILE, false if you want to fetch the item
        Returns:
        Returns the char of the tile

      • print

        public java.lang.String print(int x,
                              int y)
        Prints out a specific tile (coordinate) of a room in relation to the exact coordinates of a dungeon floor. While the room is situated on a coarse 10x10 grid (or multiple grids), the actual room tiles have fine 1x1 coordinates.
        Parameters:
        x - Fine x coordinate on the dungeon floor.
        y - Fine y coordinate on the dungeon floor.
        Returns:
        Returns the tile, with the char doubled for better console visualization.

      • getDoorwayArray

        public java.awt.Point[] getDoorwayArray()
        Returns the array of possible passageway exit points ("doorways", though not necessarily doors)
        Returns:
        array of points

      • getDoorway

        public java.awt.Point getDoorway()
        Returns a random doorway location. The doorway is basically a legal connecting point coordinate for an outbound/inbound passageway.
        Returns:
        coordiate of a random doorway

      • getShape

        public char[][] getShape()
        Return the two dimensional char array containing the room tiles.
        Returns:
        returns the array of chars representing tiles

      • getItems

        public char[][] getItems()
        Return the two dimensional char array containing the room items.
        Returns:
        returns the array of chars representing items.

      • getArea

        public int getArea()
        Returns the number of floor tiles in the room. This number is counted prior the decornerization.
        Returns:
        number of floor tiles (before decornerization)

      • resetArea

        public void resetArea()
        Resets the counter for floor tiles of the room

      • addArea

        public void addArea()
        Increments the floor tile counter by one

      • hasPivots

        public boolean hasPivots()
        If the room still has accessible pivots (points of outbound passageways) this method returns TRUE- NOTE: Each time this method is called, the number of pivots is decremented by one.
        Returns:
        true if the room has atleast 1 pivot left.

      • generatePivots

        public void generatePivots()
        Generates the starting pivots for the room. Each room should have atleast 1 pivot. A large room should have several. The pivot count has an YUUUUUGE impact on the type of floor being generated. Lot of pivots per room results a very interconnected "messy" dungeon. Limited number of pivots results a sparse dungeon. If the pivot number is TOO LOW then the algorithm might actually "break" and create a very tiny dungeon.

      • removeAllPivots

        public void removeAllPivots()
        removes all pivots

      • getRandom

        public java.util.Random getRandom()
        Returns the common random object used throughout the dungeon
        Returns:
        random object

      • setPivots

        public void setPivots(int pivots)
        Sets the pivot count manually
        Parameters:
        pivots - number of pivots
